metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Appeals relate to Excess Profits Tax liability of the appellants in respect of two chargeable accounting periods: April 1, 1944 to March 31, 1945 and April 1, 1945 to March 31, 1946.
Appellants were under an agreement dated July 11, 1945, appointed managing agents for 20 years of the Coimbatore Spinning and Weaving Co, Ltd. (the company).
Prior to October 1, 1944, the appellants were the Managing Agents of the Coimbatore Mills Agency Ltd (Agency Company) who were the Managing Agents of the company.
Year of account of the appellants ended on March 31, of the company on June 30, and of the Agency Company on September 30.

Under the agreement, remuneration provided: Office allowance at Rs. 1,500 per mensem; Commission at 1% on all purchases of cotton and stores and 2½% on all capital expenditure; Commission at 10% on the net profits of the company due and payable yearly immediately after the accounts of the company were closed.

For assessment year 1945-46, appellants submitted return inclusive of: Remuneration from Agency Company Rs. 36,000; Commission at 10% on profits from Agency Company upto 30-9-1944 Rs. 37,953; Remuneration from company from 1-10-1944 to 31-3-1945 Rs. 9,000; Commission at 1% on cotton and stores purchased during this period Rs. 21,704.

Return for 1945-46 accepted by Additional Income-tax Officer, Coimbatore, and appellants assessed to income-tax; Excess Profits Tax worked out on same basis for chargeable period ending March 31, 1945.

For assessment year 1946-47, return included: Remuneration from company for one year from 1-4-1945 Rs. 18,000; Commission at 10% on profits of company paid in December 1945 for 1-10-1944 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 1,90,889; Commission at 1% on purchases from 1-4-1945 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 16,777; Commission at 2½% on capital expenditure from 1-10-1944 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 1,690.

Tax Officer directed commission on purchases and capital expenditure be taken into account for year April 1, 1945 to March 31, 1946; Rs. 1,127 out of item attributable taken into previous year after reopening under s. 34 Income-tax Act; Commission on profits apportioned between Oct 1, 1944-March 31, 1945 and April 1-June 30, 1945 by r. 9 Sch. 1 Excess Profits Tax Act.
Tax Officer determined proportionate commission for period ending March 31, 1946.
Liabilities: For 1945-46 original IT Rs. 1,04,654, EPT Rs. 45,292; revised IT loss Rs. 36,182, EPT Rs. 1,41,962-11-0. For 1946-47 IT Rs. 1,66,271, EPT Rs. 1,13,163-5-0.
Orders confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.
On applications, Tribunal referred four questions to Madras High Court under s.66(1) IT Act and s.21 EPT Act.
High Court answered all four questions against appellants in favour of Department; appeals to SC with certificate under s.66A(2) IT Act read with s.21 EPT Act.
Appellants maintained books on cash basis; commission received from company credited after company accounts closed.
Initial assessment for Excess Profits Tax completed without apportionment appropriate to chargeable periods; Tax Officer overlooked mismatch of chargeable period and company accounting year.

legal_issues.text: Whether it was open to the Taxing Officer to re-open the assessment for 1945-46 under s.15 Excess Profits Tax Act or s.34 Income-tax Act.
Whether the commission received by the appellants was liable to be apportioned under r. 9 Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.
Whether Income-tax Officer/Excess Profits Tax Officer was right in taking action under s.34 and s.15 of the Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax Acts.
Whether provisions of r.9 Sch.1 were properly applied.
Whether Income-tax Officer/Excess Profits Tax Officer was correct in including proportionate commission income of Rs.1,127 for IT 1945-46 and Rs.1,43,163 plus Rs.1,127 for EPT ending 31 March 1945.
Whether proportionate commission of Rs.37,129 and Rs.2,299 were rightly assessed for 1946-47.

petitioner_arguments.text: It was not open to the Taxing Officer to re-open the assessment for 1945-46.

The commission received was not liable to be apportioned under r.9 Sch.1 Excess Profits Tax Act; r.9 contemplates contracts like engineering/works where profit making de die in diem, not managing agency where remuneration payable at certain time for services throughout period.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: E.D. Sassoon & Co. Ltd. v. CIT Bombay (1955) 1 SCR 313

petitioner_arguments.text: Contract of agency for 20 years regarded as annual contract; remuneration not computed at daily rate but percentage of commission on yearly profits.

respondent_arguments.text: Reopening valid under s.15 EPT Act due to underassessment from overlooking mismatch of accounting periods.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.15 Excess Profits Tax Act (similar to s.34(1) Income-tax Act pre-1948)

respondent_arguments.text: Apportionment required under r.9 Sch.1 as performance of managing agency contract extended beyond accounting period into two chargeable periods.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: r.9 Sch.1 Excess Profits Tax Act; s.2(19) Excess Profits Tax Act

court_reasoning.text: Initial assessment resulted in underassessment for EPT as chargeable period and company accounting year did not tally; Tax Officer committed error by not apportioning; open to act under s.15 EPT Act upon discovery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Manifest underassessment due to assumption periods tallied.

court_reasoning.text: r.9 Sch.1 applies where contract performance extends beyond accounting period; managing agency contract performance extended throughout company year (July 1, 1945-June 30, 1946) cutting across two chargeable periods; obliged to apportion profits properly attributable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule general, applicable to all contracts operative for fixed period including managing agency; remuneration payable after but performance throughout.

court_reasoning.text: Sassoon case inapplicable: dealt with non-receipt/accrual of income on transfer, not apportionment under r.9 to received income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court not called to apply r.9 principle in Sassoon.

holdings.text: Open to Tax Officer to reopen under s.15 EPT Act/s.34 IT Act due to underassessment.
Commission liable to apportionment under r.9 Sch.1 EPT Act as contract performance extended beyond accounting period.

precedents_cited.case_name: E. D. Sassoon & Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with indivisibility of managing agency commission on transfer; no application to apportionment of received income under r.9 Sch.1 EPT Act.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reopening assessment; reference to HC and certificate to SC.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reopening for escaped assessment; computation of profits by apportionment where contract extends beyond period; reference.

outcome.summary: The appeals fail as reopening was valid due to underassessment and apportionment under r.9 Sch.1 EPT Act was correctly applied to managing agency commission; High Court order upheld.

key_quotes.text: "The Tax Officer committed an error. He overlooked the fact that the chargeable accounting period for the assessment of Excess Profits Tax and the year of account of the company did not tally."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies reopening under s.15 EPT Act.

key_quotes.text: "The terms in which r. 9 is enacted are general the rule is applicable to all contracts which are intended to be operative for a fixed period."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies r.9 to managing agency contracts.

key_quotes.text: "The judgment of this Court in E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City has no application to this case."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes key precedent relied on by appellants.
